description.summary: Immortal bird that cyclically regenerates from its own ashes, symbolizing resurrection and renewal across multiple ancient cultures.
description.full: The phoenix is a legendary immortal bird that cyclically regenerates or is reborn from its own ashes after death. Characterized by brilliant plumage in red, gold, and purple, the phoenix is said to live for 500-1000 years. When approaching death, it builds a nest, ignites itself, burns to ashes, and is reborn from those ashes. Only one phoenix exists at any given time. The concept originated with the Egyptian Bennu bird and was adopted by Greek and Roman mythology. It became a powerful symbol of resurrection in Christianity, transformation in alchemy, and renewal across cultures.

etymology.origin: From Greek 'phoinix' (φοῖνιξ) meaning 'purple-red' (the color of the bird) or 'Phoenician' (debate exists on which came first)

related_phenomena.name: Bennu
related_phenomena.description: Egyptian heron-like deity, original phoenix concept

physical.appearance: Large bird with brilliant plumage in red, gold, and purple
physical.size: Typically described as eagle-sized or larger

features.description: Feathers in vibrant reds, golds, and purples resembling flames
Often depicted with eagle-like head and body
Flowing tail feathers of great beauty

death_rebirth: 1. Phoenix ages to end of lifespan
2. Builds nest of aromatic branches (myrrh, cinnamon, frankincense)
3. Ignites nest, burns with it to ashes
5. Young phoenix gathers ashes in myrrh egg
life_cycle.population: Only one phoenix exists at any given time

abilities.description: Dies in flames and is reborn from ashes
Tears have powerful healing properties (later tradition)

range.description: Mythological accounts from ancient Egypt, Greece, Rome, spreading throughout Western tradition

peak_activity_periods.description: Greek and Roman adoption of phoenix mythology

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Egyptian Bennu bird, associated with sun, creation, and resurrection. Adopted by Greeks and Romans from Egyptian accounts.
origins.earliest_accounts: Egyptian Bennu bird (circa 2000 BCE), associated with Ra and Osiris
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to resurrection myths, solar deities, rebirth symbolism

timeline.significance: Sacred bird of Heliopolis, symbol of Ra and resurrection
First detailed Greek account of phoenix mythology
Roman natural history description of phoenix
Phoenix becomes symbol of Christ's resurrection
Phoenix featured in medieval bestiaries as symbol of resurrection

history.modern_era: Phoenix remains powerful symbol of rebirth, transformation, and resilience in literature, film, and popular culture. No biological claims exist.

historical.name: Classical descriptions
historical.description: Detailed accounts in Herodotus, Pliny, Ovid, and others
historical.analysis: Purely symbolic creature, no historical sighting claims

mythological.name: Solar symbol
mythological.description: Phoenix represents daily solar cycle (death at night, rebirth at dawn)

mythological.name: Resurrection allegory
mythological.description: Purely symbolic representation of death and rebirth

historical_basis.name: Flamingo misidentification
historical_basis.description: Egyptian flamingos rising from hot salt flats inspired Bennu/phoenix

historical_basis.name: Symbolic origin only
historical_basis.description: No zoological basis, entirely allegorical creation

literature: Harry Potter series by J.K. Rowling (Fawkes)
The Phoenix and the Carpet by E. Nesbit (1904)
Chronicles of Narnia by C.S. Lewis

sources.title: The Phoenix: An Unnatural Biography of a Mythical Beast
